name: Tor
brand: TOR stands for The Onion Router. The onion logo visually represents the "onion routing" technique which the Tor software uses to anonymize communications.
fse_name:
The Tor Project, Inc

It is a not-for-profit organization registered in Massachusetts.

https://www.torproject.org/donate/donate. Accessed 5 September 2012.
fse_owner_founder:
Roger Dingeldine is the founder and chief spokesperson. 

Tor's Board of Directors:

Roger Dingeldine (President and Director), Ian Goldberg (Chairman of the Board), Nick Mathewson (Vice-President and Director), Frank Reiger, Rob Thomas, Meredith Hoban-Dunn, Andrew Lewman, Xianghui (Isaac) Mao, Wendy Seltzer.

source: http://www.torproject.org/about/board.html.en.
fse_significant_member:
Roger Dingeldine (arma), Jacob Appelbaum, ..

Many more listed at:
http://www.torproject.org/about/corepeople.html.en. Accessed 5 September 2012.
fse_mission_statement:
These are some excerpts from (http://www.torproject.org/about/overview.html.en):

"Tor is a network of virtual tunnels that allows people and groups to improve their privacy and security on the Internet. It also enables software developers to create new communication tools with built-in privacy features. Tor provides the foundation for a range of applications that allow organizations and individuals to share information over public networks without compromising their privacy."

"Using Tor protects you against a common form of Internet surveillance known as "traffic analysis." Traffic analysis can be used to infer who is talking to whom over a public network. Knowing the source and destination of your Internet traffic allows others to track your behavior and interests"

"Ongoing trends in law, policy, and technology threaten anonymity as never before, undermining our ability to speak and read freely online. These trends also undermine national security and critical infrastructure by making communication among individuals, organizations, corporations, and governments more vulnerable to analysis. Each new user and relay provides additional diversity, enhancing Tor's ability to put control over your security and privacy back into your hands."
op_vip_founders: Due to Tor's mission of anonymity, developers are often listed by nicknames.
op_typical_member: Hacktivists, computer security researchers, political dissidents, open source tinkerers.
history:
Tor grew out of Dingeldine's interest in anonymous communication and civil liberties (Erickson, personal communication on IRC). Dingeldine's masters thesis project at MIT was the Freehaven project (http://freehaven.net/). Freehaven is no longer developed because, as the website reads, there are unsolved problems that need to be addressed for it to be robust. For example: "There is no anonymous communications infrastructure."

Tor represents Digneldine's attempt to build the Internet's missing anonymous communications infrastructure.

The official version of Tor's history from the project website: "Tor was originally designed, implemented, and deployed as a third-generation onion routing project of the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. It was originally developed with the U.S. Navy in mind, for the primary purpose of protecting government communications. Today, it is used every day for a wide variety of purposes by normal people, the military, journalists, law enforcement officers, activists, and many others."

History of Licensing from source code:

Copyright (c) 2001-2004, Roger Dingledine
Copyright (c) 2004-2006, Roger Dingledine, Nick Mathewson
Copyright (c) 2007-2011, The Tor Project, Inc.
resource:
The principal resource that the Tor project provides is the Tor onion router – a piece of open source software that encrypts and redirects your computer's internet traffic through a series of volunteer "relays" in order to make it difficult for eaves-dropper to determine what you are doing online (e.g., who you are communicating with). The software is used to both secure your own internet communications and to relay the traffic of other Tor users. 

By using Tor in "relay mode," you add one more node to the Tor network (the network of all current Tor relays) through which encrypted traffic can be routed. This volunteer/participant-created network for anonymizing Internet communications is a secondary resource associated with the project. The more people use To, the larger the network, and the more security the software provides.
availability: The software developed by the Tor project is open source – free for anyone to download, use, and modify if they wish to.
tasks:
Tasks range from running a relay, to advocating, documenting, and ultimately, developing.

For a list of tasks and projects Tor encourages volunteers to take part in go to https://www.torproject.org/getinvolved/volunteer.html.en. Accessed 5 September 2012.
modularity: The more involved in development one becomes, the more investment necessary to accomplish tasks.  It is difficult to gauge modularity because maintenance of Tor is the primary task.  There are few standardized tasks to complete.  Coding and bug tracking may be highly involved or simple tasks depending on the problem at hand.
metrics: Tasks are measured by the degree to which Tor continues to function.
sponsors:
Electronic Frontier Foundation, Internews Network (an international non-profit dedicated to promoting independent, local news reporting), 
the International Broadcasting Bureau (IBB; an office within the Broadcasting Board of Governors which is an independent agency of the US government),  the National Science Foundation (NSF),  ITT (a for-profit company), Google.

(Tor 2007 and 2010 Form 990:
https://www.torproject.org/about/findoc/2007-TorProject-Form990.pdf
https://www.torproject.org/about/findoc/2010-TorProject-combined-Form990_PC_Audit_Results.pdf)
summary:
Tor is a routing system that enables online anonymity that is primarily driven by an FSE that sets agendas and an active OP of volunteers.

It began in 2002 and is ongoing.  It grew out of founder Richard Dingeldine's interest in anonymous communication and civil liberties. Tor represents Dingeldine's attempt to build the Internet's missing anonymous communications infrastructure. Tor was originally designed, implemented, and deployed as a third-generation onion routing project of the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. Today, it is used every day for a wide variety of purposes by normal people, the military, journalists, law enforcement officers, activists, and many others.

The principal resource that the Tor project provides is the Tor onion router – a piece of open source software that encrypts and redirects your computer's internet traffic through a series of volunteer "relays" in order to make it difficult for eaves-dropper to determine what you are doing online (e.g., who you are communicating with). The software is used to both secure your own internet communications and to relay the traffic of other Tor users.  The more people use To, the larger the network, and the more security the software provides.

Current allies include the electronic Frontier Foundation and U.S. State Department.
birder_credits: Seth Erickson. Edited by rncrooks@ucla.edu 5 September 2012.
tangible_problem_detail: Tor exists to provide a technical solution to the problem of Internet privacy.

fse_org_style.description: An organization with one leader or decision maker whose authority rests on the consent of the governed and/or his/her charisma.  Other forms of organization may supplement it (hierarchy, meritocracacy,or consensus amongst the staff or participants) but the leader's authority is final and effective.
fse_org_style.name: Charismatic Leadership/Benevelont Dictatorship

op_org_style.description: Meritocracy, in the first, most administrative sense, is a system of government or other administration (such as business administration) wherein appointments are made and responsibilities assigned to individuals based upon their "merits", namely intelligence, technical skill, credentials, creativity, and education, determined through evaluations or examinations.
op_org_style.name: Meritocracy

genus_type.description: groups organized for social or political change; independent media organizations; hacktivists; advocates and other coalitions.
genus_type.name: Activist

habitat.description: Projects that directly interacts with or depends on the ecology of low-level UNIX-based tools and Internet-based services such as UNIX operating systems, C compilers, source code management systems (SCM), POSIX standard components, internet protocols and services.
habitat.name: UNIX + Internet
